element.label: Bn
element.name: BLAST NCBI
element.about: The Basic Local Alignment Search Tool aka (BLAST) is the most widely used sequence similarity tool. There are versions of BLAST that compare protein queries to protein databases, nucleotide queries to nucleotide databases, as well as versions that translate nucleotide queries or databases in all six frames and compare to protein databases or queries.
element.author: Stephen Altschul, Warren Gish, Webb Miller, Eugene Myers, and David J. Lipman

element.label: So
element.name: SOAP
element.author: Prof. T.W. Lam, Alan Tam, Simon Wong, Edward Wu and S.M. Yiu
element.about: SOAPaligner/soap2 is a member of the SOAP (Short Oligonucleotide Analysis Package). It is an updated version of SOAP software for short oligonucleotide alignment. The new program features in super fast and accurate alignment for huge amounts of short reads generated by Illumina/Solexa Genome Analyzer.

element.label: Py
element.name: PHYLIP
element.author: Jerry Shurman, Chistopher Meacham, Mary Kuhner, Jan Yamato, Naruya Saitou and Mark Moehring
element.about: PHYLIP (the PHYLogeny Inference Package) is a package of programs for inferring phylogenies (evolutionary trees).
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Em
element.name: EMBOSS
element.author: Tim Carver and Lisa Mullan
element.about: EMBOSS is 'The European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite'. EMBOSS is a free Open Source software analysis package specially developed for the needs of the molecular biology user community. The software automatically copes with data in a variety of formats and even allows transparent retrieval of sequence data from the web.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X, Unix and Windows

element.label: Bj
element.name: BIOJAVA
element.author: Thimas Down, Michael Heuer, David Huen, Matthew Pocock, Mark Schreiber, Richard Holland, Martin Szugat, Keith James, Sylvain Foisy, Andreas Prlic, Dickson S. Guedes, Francois Pepin and Jianjiong Gao
element.about: BioJava is an open-source project dedicated to providing a Java framework for processing biological data. It includes objects for manipulating biological sequences, file parsers, DAS client and server support, access to BioSQL and Ensembl databases, tools for making sequence analysis GUIs and powerful analysis and statistical routines including a dynamic programming toolkit.

element.label: Bc
element.name: BIOCONDUCTOR
element.about: Bioconductor is an open source, open development software project to provide tools for the analysis and comprehension of high-throughput genomic data.
element.author: Vince Carey, Marc Carlson, Sean Davis and others.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Bi
element.name: Bismark
element.about: A tool to map bisulfite converted sequence reads and determine cytosine methylation states.
element.author: Felix Krueger
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Ms
element.name: SWISS-MODEL
element.about: SWISS-MODEL is a fully automated protein structure homology-modeling server, accessible via the ExPASy web server, or from the program DeepView (Swiss Pdb-Viewer). The purpose of this server is to make Protein Modelling accessible to all biochemists and molecular biologists worldwide.
element.author: Manuel Peitsch, et al
element.licence: Free, commercial users need to sign an agreement.

element.label: Hm
element.about: HMMER is used for searching sequence databases for homologs of protein sequences, and for making protein sequence alignments. It implements methods using probabilistic models called profile hidden Markov models.
element.author: Sean R. Eddy
element.name: HMMER

element.label: Mq
element.name: MAQ
element.author: Heng Li
element.about: Maq stands for Mapping and Assembly with Quality It builds assembly by mapping short reads to reference sequences. Maq is previously known as mapass2. Maq is a software that builds mapping assemblies from short reads generated by the next-generation sequencing machines. It is particularly designed for Illumina-Solexa 1G Genetic Analyzer, and has preliminary functions to handle ABI SOLiD data.

element.label: Bs
element.author: Ewan Birney
element.about: BioSQL is a generic unifying schema for storing sequences from different sources, for instance Genbank or Swissprot. BioSQL is meant to be a common data storage layer supported by all the different Bio* projects, Bioperl, Biojava, Biopython, and Bioruby. Entries stored through an application written in, say, Bioperl could be retrieved by another written in Biojava.
element.name: bioSQL
element.licence: GNU Lesser General Public Licence v 3

element.label: Eh
element.name: eHIVE
element.about: This is a distributed processing system based on 'autonomous agents' and the behavioural structure of honey bees. It implements all functionality of both data-flow graphs and block-branch diagrams which should allow it to codify any program, algorithm, or parallel processing job control system. It is not bound to any processing 'farm' system and can be adapted to any GRID.
element.author: Abel Ureta-Vidal, Jessica Severin, Michael Schuster

element.label: En
element.name: ENSEMBL API
element.author: Glenn Proctor, Ian Longden and Patrick Meidl
element.about: The Ensembl API (application programming interface) is a framework for applications that need to access or store data in Ensembl's databases.

element.label: Br
element.name: bioRUBY
element.author: Toshiaki Katayama
element.about: BioRuby is an open source Ruby library for developing bioinformatics software.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: La
element.name: LAGAN
element.author: Michael Brudno
element.about: The LAGAN Tookit consists of four components:CHAOS, LAGAN, Multi-LAGAN,Shuffle-LAGAN.

element.name: Mauve
element.label: Mve
element.author: Darling AE, Mau B, Perna NT
element.about: Mauve is a system for efficiently constructing multiple genome alignments in the presence of large-scale evolutionary events such as rearrangement and inversion. Multiple genome alignment provides a basis for research into comparative genomics and the study of evolutionary dynamics. Aligning whole genomes is a fundamentally different problem than aligning short sequences. Mauve has been developed with the idea that a multiple genome aligner should require only modest computational resources. It employs algorithmic techniques that scale well in the amount of sequence being aligned. For example, a pair of Y. pestis genomes can be aligned in under a minute, while a group of 9 divergent Enterobacterial genomes can be aligned in a few hours.

element.label: Hh
element.name: HHpred
element.about: The primary aim in developing HHpred was to provide biologists with a method for sequence database searching and structure prediction that is as easy to use as BLAST or PSI-BLAST and that is at the same time much more sensitive in finding remote homologs. In fact, HHpred's sensitivity is competitive with the most powerful servers for structure prediction currently available.
element.author: Soding, Biegert, Lupas, et al

element.label: Mu
element.name: MUMmer
element.about: MUMmer is a system for rapidly aligning entire genomes, whether in complete or draft form. For example, MUMmer 3.0 can find all 20-basepair or longer exact matches between a pair of 5-megabase genomes in 13.7 seconds, using 78 MB of memory, on a 2.4 GHz Linux desktop computer.
element.author: Stefan Kurtz, Adam Phillippy, Art Delcher and Steven Salzberg

element.label: Bo
element.name: Bowtie
element.author: Ben Langmead and Cole Trapnell
element.about: Bowtie is an ultrafast, memory-efficient short read aligner geared toward quickly aligning large sets of short DNA sequences (reads) to large genomes. It aligns 35-base-pair reads to the human genome at a rate of 25 million reads per hour on a typical workstation.

element.label: Cl
element.about: Clustal W is a general purpose multiple alignment program for DNA or proteins. Clustal 2 comes in two flavors: the command-line version ClustalW and the graphical version ClustalX.
element.author: Higgins DG, Sharp PM
element.name: CLUSTALW

element.label: Pe
element.about: Pecan is a consistency based multiple-alignment program developed by Benedict Paten in Ewan Birney's group at the EBI.
element.author: Benedict Paten
element.name: PECAN

element.label: Mi
element.name: MIRA 97
element.about: MIRA is a whole genome shotgun and EST sequence assembler for Sanger, 454, Solexa (Illumina), IonTorrent data and PacBio. It can be seen as a Swiss army knife of sequence assembly developed and used in the past 12 years to get assembly jobs done efficiently - and especially accurately.
element.author: Bastien Chevreux

element.label: Se
element.name: SEQCLEAN
element.about: A script for automated trimming and validation of ESTs or other DNA sequences by screening for various contaminants, low quality and low-complexity sequences.
element.author: The Gene Indices Group -Geo Pertea-

element.label: Jm
element.name: Jmol
element.about: Jmol is a free, open source molecule viewer for students, educators, and researchers in chemistry and biochemistry.
element.author: Egon Willighagen, et al

element.label: Sd
element.name: SOAP: DE NOVO 2
element.about: SOAPdenovo is a novel short-read assembly method that can build a de novo draft assembly for the human-sized genomes. The program is specially designed to assemble Illumina GA short reads.
element.author: BGI

element.label: Un
element.name: UNIGENE
element.about: UniGene computationally identifies transcripts from the same locus; analyzes expression by tissue, age, and health status; and reports related proteins (protEST) and clone resources.
element.author: Boguski MS, Schuler GD

element.label: Gl
element.name: GLIMMER 3
element.about: Glimmer is a system for finding genes in microbial DNA, especially the genomes of bacteria, archaea, and viruses. Glimmer (Gene Locator and Interpolated Markov ModelER) uses interpolated Markov models (IMMs) to identify the coding regions and distinguish them from noncoding DNA.
element.author: Arthur Delcher

element.label: Cd
element.name: CD-HIT
element.about: CD-HIT is a very widely used program for clustering and comparing protein or nucleotide sequences.
element.author: Wizhong Li, Adam Godzik, Lukasz Jaroszewski

element.label: Tr
element.name: tRNAscan
element.author: Oeter Schattner, Angela N. Brooks and Todd M. Lowe
element.about: tRNAscan-SE was designed to make rapid, sensitive searches of genomic sequence feasible using the selectivity of the Cove analysis package. Search for tRNA genes in genomic sequence.tRNAscan-SE identifies transfer RNA genes in genomic DNA or RNA sequences.

element.label: Bm
element.name: bioMART
element.author: Arek Kasprzyk
element.about: The purpose of BioMart is to convert one or more data source (flat files or relational) into data marts which can be accessed via its tandardised web browser interface and also via its Perl, Java and webservice APIs.

element.label: Ta
element.name: TAVERNA
element.author: myGrid (University of Manchester) and EBI)
element.about: Taverna is an open source and domain-independent Workflow Management System – a suite of tools used to design and execute scientific workflows and aid in silico experimentation.

element.label: Eb
element.name: ENSEMBL BROWSER
element.author: EBI and Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute
element.about: Ensembl is a joint project between EMBL - EBI and the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute to develop a software system which produces and maintains automatic annotation on selected eukaryotic genomes.

element.label: Bp
element.name: bioPERL
element.author: Chris Dagdigian, Richard Resnick, Lew Gramer,Alessandro Guffanti and others.
element.about: BioPerl is a toolkit of perl modules useful in building bioinformatics solutions in Perl. BioPerl project is an international association of developers of open source Perl tools for bioinformatics, genomics and life science research.

element.label: Pl
element.name: PLINK
element.about: PLINK is a free, open-source whole genome association analysis toolset, designed to perform a range of basic, large-scale analyses in a computationally efficient manner.
element.author: Shaun Purcell

element.label: Sa
element.name: SAMtools
element.author: Heng Li,Bob Handsaker, Jue Ruan, John Marshall and Petr Danecek
element.about: SAMtools is a set of utilities for efficiently processing nucleotide alignments in the Sequence Alignment/Map format (SAM) and its binary representation (BAM format), and accurately calling the SNPs and short INDELs from the alignment.

element.label: Ps
element.name: PSIPRED
element.about: The PSIPRED Protein Sequence Analysis Workbench aggregates several UCL structure prediction methods into one location. Users can submit a protein sequence, perform the predictions of their choice and receive the results of the prediction via e-mail or the web.
element.author: Jones, Buchan, Nugent, Minneci, Bryson et al

element.label: Ss
element.name: SSAHA
element.about: ssaha is a tool for rapidly finding near exact matches in DNA or protein databases. The name is an acronym standing for Sequence Search and Alignment by Hashing Algorithm. It works by converting a sequence database into a hash table. This is then rapidly quizzed for hits, which are concatenated into matches.
element.author: Prof. T.W. Lam, Alan Tam, Simon Wong, Edward Wu and S.M. Yiu

element.label: Bw
element.name: BWA
element.about: Burrows-Wheeler Aligner (BWA) is an efficient program that aligns relatively short nucleotide sequences against a long reference sequence such as the human genome. It implements two algorithms, bwa-short and BWA-SW.
element.author: Heng Li, Chi-Kwong, Nong Ge and Yuta Mori.

element.label: Cf
element.name: T-COFFEE
element.about: T-Coffee is a multiple sequence alignment package. You can use T-Coffee to align sequences or to combine the output of your favorite alignment methods (Clustal, Mafft, Probcons, Muscle...) into one unique alignment.
element.author: Cedric Notredame, Higgins DG, Heringa J.

element.label: Pr
element.name: PRANK
element.about: PRANK is a probabilistic multiple alignment program for DNA, codon and amino-acid sequences that has been shown to produce exceptionally accurate alignments for evolutionary analyses. It is based on a novel algorithm that treats insertions correctly and avoids over-estimation of the number of deletion events.
element.author: Ari Löytynoja

element.label: Ce
element.name: CELERA
element.about: Celera Assembler is a de novo whole-genome shotgun (WGS) DNA sequence assembler.Celera Assembler is a de novo whole-genome shotgun (WGS) DNA sequence assembler.
element.author: Celera Gomes

element.label: Fo
element.name: FORGE
element.about: Forge is a classic Overlap layout consensus genome assembler. Implemented in C++ and using the parallel MPI library, it runs on one or more machines in a network and can scale to very large numbers of reads provided there is enough collective memory on the machines used.
element.author: Darren Platt and Dirk Evers

element.name: RasMol
element.label: Rm
element.author: R. A. Sayle and E. J. Milner-White
element.about: RasMol is an important scientific tool for visualisation of molecules created by Roger Sayle in 1992. RasMol is used by hundreds of thousands of users world-wide to view macromolecules and to prepare publication-quality images.

element.label: Sg
element.name: SGA
element.author: Jared Simpson and Richard Durbin
element.about: SGA is a de novo genome assembler based on the concept of string graphs. The major goal of SGA is to be very memory efficient, which is achieved by using a compressed representation of DNA sequence reads.

element.label: Cu
element.name: CUFFLINKS
element.author: Cole Trapnell, Adam Roberts, Ali Mortazavi, Steven Salzberg, Barabara Wold, Lior Pachter etc.
element.about: Cufflinks assembles transcripts, estimates their abundances, and tests for differential expression and regulation in RNA-Seq samples. It accepts aligned RNA-Seq reads and assembles the alignments into a parsimonious set of transcripts. Cufflinks then estimates the relative abundances of these transcripts based on how many reads support each one, taking into account biases in library preparation protocols.

element.label: Eu
element.name: EUGENE
element.author: P. Bardou, MJ. Cros, S. Foissac, J Gouzy, A. and Moisan, T. Schiex
element.about: An open gene finder for eukaryotic organisms. Compared to most existing gene finders, EuGène is characterized by its ability to simply integrate arbitrary sources of information in its prediction process.

element.label: Fx
element.name: FASTX-Toolkit
element.author: Assaf Gordon
element.about: The FASTX-Toolkit is a collection of command line tools for Short-Reads FASTA/FASTQ files preprocessing.

element.label: Rn
element.name: RNAfold
element.author: M Zuker and P Stiegler
element.about: The RNAfold web server will predict secondary structures of single stranded RNA or DNA sequences.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: In
element.name: INTERMINE
element.author: Richard Smith, Jakub Kulaviak, Julie Sullivan, Mather Wakeling, Xavier Watkins
element.about: InterMine is a powerful open source data warehouse system. Using InterMine, you can create databases of biological data accessed by sophisticated web query tools. InterMine includes an attractive, user-friendly web interface that works 'out of the box' and can be easily customised for your specific needs.

element.label: Gx
element.name: GALAXY
element.author: Enis Afgan, Guru Ananda and Dannon Baker
element.about: Galaxy is a scientific workflow and data integration platform that aims to make computational biology accessible to research scientists that do not have computer programming experience.

element.label: Ap
element.name: APOLLO
element.author: Ed Lee, Nomi Harris, Steve Searle, Michele Clamp, Suzanna Lewis, John Richter and Mark Gibson
element.about: Apollo is a genome annotation viewer and editor. It was developed as a collaboration between the Berkeley Drosophila Genome Project (part of the FlyBase consortium) and The Sanger Institute in Cambridge, UK. Apollo allows researchers to explore genomic annotations at many levels of detail, and to perform expert annotation curation, all in a graphical environment.

element.label: Ig
element.name: IGB
element.about: The Integrated Genome Browser (IGB, pronounced Ig-Bee) is an interactive, zoomable, scrollable software program you can use to visualize and explore genome-scale data sets.
element.author: Gregg Helt

element.label: Ut
element.name: UTGB
element.author: Shinichi Morishita, Taro Saito, Jun Yoshimura, Koichiro Higasa, Hiroshi Minoshima, Reginaldo Kuroshu and Atsushi Sasaki.
element.about: UTGB Toolkit is an open-source software for developing personalized genome browsers.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Am
element.author: Chrisopher Quince, Andres Lanzen, Russell J Davenport
element.about: AmpliconNoise is a collection of programs for the removal of noise from 454 sequenced PCR amplicons. It involves two steps the removal of noise from the sequencing itself and the removal of PCR point errors. This project also includes the Perseus algorithm for chimera removal.
element.name: AMPLICONNOISE

element.label: Qi
element.name: QIIME
element.about: QIIME (canonically pronounced ‘Chime’) is a pipeline for performing microbial community analysis that integrates many third party tools which have become standard in the field. QIIME can run on a laptop, a supercomputer, and systems in between such as multicore desktops.
element.author: Developed by Knight Lab at the University of Colorado at Boulder

element.label: Ex
element.name: EXONERATE
element.author: Guy St.C. Slater
element.about: exonerate is a general tool for sequence comparison. It uses the C4 dynamic programming library. It is designed to be both general and fast. It can produce either gapped or ungapped alignments, according to a variety of different alignment models.

element.label: Bf
element.about: BFAST (Blat-like Fast Accurate Search Tool) facilitates the fast and accurate mapping of short reads to reference sequences. BFAST was designed to facilitate whole-genome resequencing, where mapping billions of short reads with variants is of utmost importance. BFAST supports both Illumina and ABI SOLiD data, as well as any other Next-Generation Sequencing Technology (454, Helicos), with particular emphasis on sensitivity towards errors, SNPs and especially indels.
element.author: Nils Homer
element.name: BFAST

element.label: Ma
element.name: MAFFT
element.about: MAFFT is a multiple sequence alignment program for amino acid or nucleotide sequences. It has several different options for various types of alignment problems. Progressive alignment options can be applied to a large number of homologous sequences.
element.author: Kazutaka Katoh, Charles Plessy

element.label: Mv
element.name: MAVID
element.about: MAVID is a multiple sequence alignment program suitable for the alignment of large numbers of DNA sequences. The sequences can be small mitochondrial genomes or large genomic regions up to megabases long.
element.author: Nicolas Bray, Lior Pachter

element.label: Ar
element.name: ARACHNE
element.about: ARACHNE is a program for assembling data from whole genome shotgun sequencing experiments. It was designed for long reads from Sanger sequencing technology, and has been used extensively to assemble many genomes, including many that are large and highly repetitive.
element.author: Jaffe DB

element.label: Me
element.name: MERACULOUS
element.author: Chapman JA, Ho I, Sunkara S, Luo S, Schroth GP
element.about: Meraculous relies on an efficient and conservative traversal of the subgraph of the k-mer (deBruijn) graph of oligonucleotides with unique high quality extensions in the dataset, avoiding an explicit error correction step as used in other short-read assemblers.

element.label: Co
element.name: CORTEX_CON_RP
element.about: Cortex is an efficient and low-memory software framework for analysis of genomes using sequence data.
element.author: Mario Caccamo and Zamin Iqbal

element.label: Pa
element.name: PE-ASSEMBLER
element.author: Nuwantha Ariaratne P., Sung WK.
element.about: A simple extension approach to assembling paired-end reads and capable of parallelization.

element.label: Oa
element.name: OASES
element.about: Oases is a de novo transcriptome assembler designed to produce transcripts from short read sequencing technologies, such as Illumina, SOLiD, or 454 in the absence of any genomic assembly.
element.author: Marcel Schulz and Daniel Zerbino

element.label: Ep
element.name: ENSEMBL PIPELINE
element.author: EBI and Wellcome Trust Sanger institute.
element.about: Ensembl is a joint project between EMBL - EBI and the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute to develop a software system which produces and maintains automatic annotation on selected eukaryotic genomes.

element.label: Fq
element.name: FastQC
element.author: Simon Andrews
element.about: A quality control tool for high throughput sequence data.

element.name: SignalP
element.label: Si
element.licence: Web unrestricted, Download free for academics
element.author: Henrik Nielsen, Jacob Engelbrecht, Søren Brunak and Gunnar von Heijne
element.about: SignalP server predicts the presence and location of signal peptide cleavage sites in amino acid sequences from different organisms: Gram-positive prokaryotes, Gram-negative prokaryotes, and eukaryotes. The method incorporates a prediction of cleavage sites and a signal peptide/non-signal peptide prediction based on a combination of several artificial neural networks.

element.label: Ch
element.name: CHADO
element.author: Chris Mungall and Dave Emmert
element.about: Chado is a relational database schema that underlies many GMOD installations. The Chado schema has been designed with modularity and compartmentalization of function in mind.

element.label: Kn
element.author: Iris Ada, Michael Berhold and Thomas Gabriel
element.about: KNIME (Konstanz Information Miner) is a user-friendly and comprehensive open-source data integration, processing, analysis, and exploration platform.
element.name: KNIME

element.label: Gb
element.name: GBROWSE
element.author: Lincoln Stein
element.about: GBrowse is a combination of database and interactive web pages for manipulating and displaying annotations on genomes.

element.label: Nc
element.name: NCBI MapViewer
element.about: The Map Viewer provides special browsing capabilities for a subset of organisms in Entrez Genomes. The viewer allows you to view and search an organism's complete genome, display chromosome maps, and zoom into progressively greater levels of detail, down to the sequence data for a region of interest.
element.os: Mac OS X, Unix and Windows

element.label: By
element.author: Tiago Antao, Sebastian Bassi, Jeffrey Chang etc.
element.about: Biopython is a set of freely available tools for biological computation written in Python by an international team of developers.
element.name: BioPython

element.label: Pic
element.about: Picard comprises Java-based command-line utilities that manipulate SAM files, and a Java API (SAM-JDK) for creating new programs that read and write SAM files. Both SAM text format and SAM binary (BAM) format are supported.
element.name: Picard

element.label: Vc
element.name: VCFtools
element.author: Adam Auton and Petr Danecek
element.about: Welcome to VCFtools - a program package designed for working with VCF files, such as those generated by the 1000 Genomes Project. VCFtools is split into two sections: The vcftool binary program/ The VCF perl module.

element.label: Fa
element.name: FASTA
element.author: David Lipman and William Pearson
element.about: FASTA is a DNA and protein sequence alignment software package first described (as FASTP). Its legacy is the FASTA format which is now ubiquitous in bioinformatics. FASTA is pronounced 'fast A', and stands for 'FAST-All', because it works with any alphabet, an extension of 'FAST-P' (protein) and 'FAST-N' (nucleotide) alignment.

element.label: Sm
element.name: SMALT
element.about: SMALT efficiently aligns DNA sequencing reads with genomic reference sequences. The software employs a perfect hash index of short words (< 21 nucleotides long), sampled at equidistant steps along the genomic reference sequences. For each read, potentially matching segments in the reference are identified from seed matches in the index and subsequently aligned with the read using a banded Smith-Waterman algorithm. Reads from a wide range of sequencing platforms, for example Illumina, Roche-454, Ion Torrent, PacBio or ABI-Sanger, can be processed including paired-end reads.
element.author: Hannes Ponstigl

element.label: Ml
element.about: MUSCLE is a program for creating multiple alignments of amino acid or nucleotide sequences. A range of options is provided that give you the choice of optimizing accuracy, speed, or some compromise between the two.
element.author: Robert C. Edgar
element.name: MUSCLE

element.label: Pb
element.name: PROBCONS
element.about: ProbCons is an open source probabilistic consistency-based multiple alignment of amino acid sequences. It is an efficient protein multiple sequence alignment program, which has demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in accuracy compared to several leading alignment tools.
element.author: Chuong Do, Michael Brudno

element.label: Ph
element.name: PHUSION(2)
element.about: Phusion is a software package for assembling genome sequences from whole genome shotgun(WGS) reads. The Phusion assembler is involved in assembling a number of genomes, such as mouse, zebrafish, C. briggsae, Schistosoma mansoni etc.
element.author: Mullikin JC and Zemin Ning

element.label: Qu
element.name: QUAKE
element.author: David R. Kelly, Michael C. Schatz, Steven L. Salzberg
element.about: Quake is a package to correct substitution sequencing errors in experiments with deep coverage (e.g. >15X), specifically intended for Illumina sequencing reads. Quake adopts the k-mer error correction framework, first introduced by the EULER genome assembly package.

element.label: Al
element.name: ALLPATHS-LG
element.author: Gnerre S.
element.about: ALLPATHS LG is a whole-genome shotgun assembler that can generate high-quality genome assemblies using short reads (~100bp) such as those produced by the new generation of sequencers. The significant difference between ALLPATHS and traditional assemblers such as Arachne is that ALLPATHS assemblies are not necessarily linear, but instead are presented in the form of a graph.

element.label: Ba
element.name: BAMBUS 2 09
element.author: Segey Koren and Mihai Pop
element.about: Bambus 2.0, the second generation Bambus scaffolder for polymorphic and metagenomic data.

element.name: Trinity
element.label: Ty
element.author: Grabherr MG, Haas BJ, Yassour M, Levin JZ, Thompson DA, Amit I, Adiconis X, Fan L, Raychowdhury R, Zeng Q, Chen Z, Mauceli E, Hacohen N, Gnirke A, Rhind N, di Palma F, Birren BW, Nusbaum C, Lindblad-Toh K, Friedman N, Regev A.
element.about: Trinity, developed at the Broad Institute and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, represents a novel method for the efficient and robust de novo reconstruction of transcriptomes from RNA-seq data. Trinity combines three independent software modules: Inchworm, Chrysalis, and Butterfly, applied sequentially to process large volumes of RNA-seq reads. Trinity partitions the sequence data into many individual de Bruijn graphs, each representing the transcriptional complexity at at a given gene or locus, and then processes each graph independently to extract full-length splicing isoforms and to tease apart transcripts derived from paralogous genes.

element.label: Sn
element.name: SNAP
element.author: Ian Korf
element.about: The SNAP gene finder is HMM-based like Genscan and attempts to be more adaptable to different organisms, addressing problems related to using a gene finder on a genome sequence that it was not trained against.

element.name: RepeatMasker
element.label: Rk
element.author: Smit, AFA, Hubley, R, Green, P.
element.about: RepeatMasker is a program that screens DNA sequences for interspersed repeats and low complexity DNA sequences. The output of the program is a detailed annotation of the repeats that are present in the query sequence as well as a modified version of the query sequence in which all the annotated repeats have been masked (default: replaced by Ns). On average, almost 50% of a human genomic DNA sequence currently will be masked by the program. Sequence comparisons in RepeatMasker are performed by one of several popular search engines including, cross_match, ABBlast/WUBlast, RMBlast and Decypher.

element.name: VariantTools
element.label: Vt
element.author: F Anthony San Lucas, Gao Wang, Paul Scheet, Bo Peng
element.about: Variant tools is a software tool for the annotation, selection, and analysis of variants in the context of next-gen sequencing analysis. Unlike some other tools used for Next-Gen sequencing analysis, variant tools is project based and provide a whole set of tools to manipulate and analyze genetic variants.

element.label: Pd
element.name: PDB
element.author: Consortium.
element.about: The Protein Data Bank (PDB) archive is the single worldwide repository of information about the 3D structures of large biological molecules, including proteins and nucleic acids. These are the molecules of life that are found in all organisms including bacteria, yeast, plants, flies, other animals, and humans. Understanding the shape of a molecule helps to understand how it works. This knowledge can be used to help deduce a structure's role in human health and disease, and in drug development. The structures in the archive range from tiny proteins and bits of DNA to complex molecular machines like the ribosome.
element.licence: Data contained in PDF is free of all copyright restrictions and made fully and freely available for both non-commercial and commercial use.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Up
element.name: UniProt
element.author: Consortium led by Rolf Apweiler, Cathy Wu, and Ioannis Xenarios.
element.about: The mission of UniProt is to provide the scientific community with a comprehensive, high-quality and freely accessible resource of protein sequence and functional information.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Iv
element.name: IGV
element.author: Jim Robinson, Helga Thorvaldsdottir, Jacob Silterra and Marc-Danie Nazaire.
element.about: The Integrative Genomics Viewer (IGV) is a high-performance visualization tool for interactive exploration of large, integrated datasets. It supports a wide variety of data types including sequence alignments, microarrays, and genomic annotations.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Ag
element.name: ARGO
element.author: Reinhard Engels
element.about: The Argo Genome Browser is the Broad Institute's production tool for visualizing and manually annotating whole genomes.

element.label: At
element.name: ARTEMIS
element.author: Tim Carver, Giles Velarde, Matthew Berriman, Julian Parkhill and Jacqueline McQuillan.
element.about: Artemis is a free genome browser and annotation tool that allows visualisation of sequence features, next generation data and the results of analyses within the context of the sequence, and also its six-frame translation.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X, Unix and Windows.

element.label: As
element.author: Dmitrijs Lvov and A.V. Favorov
element.about: APSampler is a tool that allows multi-locus and multi-level association analysis of genotypic and phenotypic data. The goal is to find the allelic sets (patterns) that are associated with phenotype.
element.name: APSampler

element.label: Ge
element.author: GenABEL project developers
element.about: The mission of the GenABEL project is to provide a free framework for collaborative, robust, transparent, open-source based development of statistical genomics methodology.
element.name: GenABEL
ACT
element.label: Ac
element.author: Carver TJ, Rutherford KM, Berriman M, Rajandream MA, Barrell BG and Parkhill J
element.about: ACT is a free tool for displaying pairwise comparisons between two or more DNA sequences. It can be used to identify and analyse regions of similarity and difference between genomes and to explore conservation of synteny, in the context of the entire sequences and their annotation.

element.name: rna-star
element.label: Rs
element.author: Alexander Dobin, Carrie A. Davis, Felix Schlesinger, Jorg Drenkow, Chris Zaleski, Sonali Jha, Philippe Batut, Mark Chaisson and Thomas R. Gingeras
element.about: To align our large (>80 billon reads) ENCODE Transcriptome RNA-seq dataset, we developed the Spliced Transcripts Alignment to a Reference (STAR) software based on a previously undescribed RNA-seq alignment algorithm that uses sequential maximum mappable seed search in uncompressed suffix arrays followed by seed clustering and stitching procedure.

element.label: Po
element.author: Oscar Westesson and Ian Holmes
element.about: Prot Pal is a software tool for multiple sequence alignment, ancestral reconstruction, and measurement of indel rates on a phylogenetic tree.
element.name: PROT PAL

element.label: Fs
element.author: Robert Bradley, Colin Dewey, Jaeyoung Do, Sudeep Juvekar, Lior Pachter, Adam Roberts, and Michael Smoot.
element.about: FSA is a probabilistic multiple sequence alignment algorithm which uses a "distance-based" approach to aligning homologous protein, RNA or DNA sequences.
element.name: FSA

element.label: Pi
element.name: PRICE
element.about: We are pleased to release PRICE (Paired-Read Iterative Contig Extension), a de novo genome assembler implemented in C++. Its name describes the strategy that it implements for genome assembly: PRICE uses paired-read information to iteratively increase the size of existing contigs. Initially, those contigs can be individual reads from a subset of the paired-read dataset, non-paired reads from sequencing technologies that provide non-paired data, or contigs that were output from a prior run of PRICE or any other assembler.

element.label: Ve
element.name: VELVET
element.about: Velvet is short read assembler which uses de Bruijn graphs to assemble next-generation sequencing reads into useable contigs. It handles mixed length reads as well as paired-end reads.
element.author: Daniel Zerbino and Ewan Birney

element.label: Sp
element.author: Anton Bankevich, Sergey Nurk, Dmitry Antipov etc.'c
element.about: SPAdes stands for St. Petersburg genome assembler. It is intended for both standard (multicell) and single-cell MDA bacteria assemblies.
element.name: SPAdes
Contrail
element.label: Cn
element.author: Michael Schatz, Jeremy Chambers, Avijit Gupta, Rushil Gupta, David Kelley, Jeremy Lewi, Deepak Nettem, Dan Sommer, and Mihai Pop
element.about: Similar to other leading short read assembler, Contrail relies on the graph-theoretic framework of de Bruijn graphs. However, unlike these programs, which require large RAM resources, Contrail relies on Hadoop to iteratively transform an on-disk representation of the assembly graph, allowing an in depth analysis even for large genomes.

element.label: Au
element.name: AUGUSTUS
element.author: Mario Stanke and Oliver Keller
element.about: AUGUSTUS is a program that predicts genes in eukaryotic genomic sequences. It can be run on this web server, on a new web server for larger input files or be downloaded and run locally.

element.label: Mg
element.name: MGENE
element.about: mGene is a computational tool for the genome-wide prediction of protein coding genes from eukaryotic DNA sequences.
element.author: Gunnar Raetsch, Gabriele Schweikert, Jonas Behr

element.name: MetaBioME
element.label: Mm
element.author: Vineet Kumar Sharma, Naveen Kumar, Tulika Prakash, Todd D. Taylor
element.about: MetaBioME is a web resource to find novel homologs for known Commercially Useful Enzymes (CUEs) in metagenomic datasets and completed bacterial genomes.

element.name: JalView
element.label: Jv
element.author: Waterhouse AM, Procter JB, Martin DMA, Clamp M, Barton GJ
element.about: Jalview is a free program developed for the interactive editing, analysis and visualization of multiple sequence alignments. It can also work with sequence annotation, secondary structure information, phylogenetic trees and 3D molecular structures.

element.name: CATH
element.label: Ct
element.author: Sillitoe I, Cuff AL, Dessailly BH, Dawson NL, Furnham N, Lee D, Lees JG, Lewis TE, Studer RA, Rentzsch R, Yeats C, Thornton JM, Orengo CA
element.about: The CATH database is a hierarchical domain classification of protein structures in the Protein Data Bank. Protein structures are classified using a combination of automated and manual procedures.

element.label: Tg
element.author: Robert Davey and Mario Caccamo
element.about: MISO (Managing Information for Sequencing Operations) is a new open-source Lab Information Management System (LIMS) under development at TGAC, specifically designed for tracking next-generation sequencing experiments.
element.name: MISO
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Da
element.author: Thomas Down
element.about: Dalliance is a track-oriented genome viewer similar to Ensembl, UCSC, or GBrowse. However, it is a little different in operation because it uses recent extensions to web standards (HTML 5) to offer a higher level of interactivity than most previous genome viewers.
element.name: DALLIANCE BROWSER
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Jb
element.name: JBROWSE
element.author: Rober Buels and Mitch Skinner
element.about: JBrowse is a JavaScript genome browser with an emphasis on portability. Browse is the official successor to GBrowse.

element.label: Mb
element.author: John Huelsenbeck, Bret Larget, Paul van der Mark, Fredrik Ronquist, Donald Simon and Maxim Teslenko.
element.about: MrBayes is a program for Bayesian inference and model choice across a wide range of phylogenetic and evolutionary models. MrBayes uses Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods to estimate the posterior distribution of model parameters.
element.name: MrBayes

element.label: Pn
element.author: Adam Siepel, Melissa Hubisz and Katie Pollard
element.about: PHAST is a freely available software package for comparative and evolutionary genomics. It consists of about half a dozen major programs, plus more than a dozen utilities for manipulating sequence alignments, phylogenetic trees, and genomic annotations (see left panel).
element.name: PhastCons
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.name: UGENE
element.label: Ug
element.author: Konstantin Okonechnikov; Olga Golosova; Mikhail Fursov
element.about: Unipro UGENE is a multiplatform open-source software with the main goal of assisting molecular biologists without much expertise in bioinformatics to manage, analyze and visualize their data. UGENE integrates widely used bioinformatics tools within a common user interface. The toolkit supports multiple biological data formats and allows the retrieval of data from remote data sources. It provides visualization modules for biological objects such as annotated genome sequences, Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) assembly data, multiple sequence alignments, phylogenetic trees and 3D structures. Most of the integrated algorithms are tuned for maximum performance by the usage of multithreading and special processor instructions. UGENE includes a visual environment for creating reusable workflows that can be launched on local resources or in a High Performance Computing (HPC) environment.

element.name: GMAP/GSNAP
element.label: Gm
element.licence: Free (custom Genentech) but do not redistribute modifications
element.author: Thomas D. Wu, Colin K. Watanabe, Serban Nacu
element.about: GMAP: A Genomic Mapping and Alignment Program for mRNA and EST Sequences, and GSNAP: Genomic Short-read Nucleotide Alignment Program

element.label: Ji
element.name: JIGSAW
element.author: Jonathan Edward Allen
element.about: JIGSAW is a program designed to use the output from gene finders, splice site prediction programs and sequence alignments to predict gene models. JIGSAW is available for all species. We have tested JIGSAW on Human, Rice (Oryza sativa), Arabidopsis thaliana, C. elegans, Brugia malayi, Cryptococcus neoformans, Entamoeba histolytica, Theileria parva, Aspergillus fumigatus, Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium yoelii.

element.name: Tophat
element.label: Th
element.author: Daehwan Kim, Geo Pertea, Cole Trapnell, Harold Pimentel, Ryan Kelley and Steven L Salzberg
element.about: TopHat is a fast splice junction mapper for RNA-Seq reads. It aligns RNA-Seq reads to mammalian-sized genomes using the ultra high-throughput short read aligner Bowtie, and then analyzes the mapping results to identify splice junctions between exons.

element.name: RSEM
element.label: Re
element.author: Bo Li
element.about: RSEM is a software package for estimating gene and isoform expression levels from RNA-Seq data. The RSEM package provides an user-friendly interface, supports threads for parallel computation of the EM algorithm, single-end and paired-end read data, quality scores, variable-length reads and RSPD estimation. In addition, it provides posterior mean and 95% credibility interval estimates for expression levels. For visualization, It can generate BAM and Wiggle files in both transcript-coordinate and genomic-coordinate.

element.name: Flexbar
element.label: Fb
element.author: Matthias Dodt, Johannes T. Roehr, Rina Ahmed, Christoph Dieterich
element.about: Flexbar preprocesses high-throughput sequencing data efficiently. It demultiplexes barcoded runs and removes adapter sequences. Moreover, trimming and filtering features are provided. Flexbar increases read mapping rates and improves genome and transcriptome assemblies. It supports next-generation sequencing data in fasta/q and csfasta/q format from Illumina, Roche 454, and the SOLiD platform.

element.name: ENA
element.label: Ea
element.about: The European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) captures and presents information relating to experimental workflows that are based around nucleotide sequencing. A typical workflow includes the isolation and preparation of material for sequencing, a run of a sequencing machine in which sequencing data are produced and a subsequent bioinformatic analysis pipeline. ENA records this information in a data model that covers input information (sample, experimental setup, machine configuration), output machine data (sequence traces, reads and quality scores) and interpreted information (assembly, mapping, functional annotation).

element.label: Pf
element.author: L. Aravind, Adam Godik and Val Wood
element.about: The Pfam database is a large collection of protein families, each represented by multiple sequence alignments and hidden Markov models (HMMs).
element.name: Pfam
Savant
element.label: Sv
element.author: Fiume M, Smith EJ, Brook A, Strbenac D, Turner B, Mezlini AM, Robinson MD, Wodak SJ, Brudno M.
element.about: Savant is a next-generation genome browser designed for the latest generation of genome data.

element.name: Genbank
element.label: Gk
element.about: GenBank ® is the NIH genetic sequence database, an annotated collection of all publicly available DNA sequences (Nucleic Acids Research, 2013 Jan;41(D1):D36-42). GenBank is part of the International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration , which comprises the DNA DataBank of Japan (DDBJ), the European Molecular Biology Laboratory (EMBL), and GenBank at NCBI. These three organizations exchange data on a daily basis.

element.name: Interpro
element.label: Ip
element.about: InterPro is a resource that provides functional analysis of protein sequences by classifying them into families and predicting the presence of domains and important sites. To classify proteins in this way, InterPro uses predictive models, known as signatures, provided by several different databases (referred to as member databases) that make up the InterPro consortium.

element.name: ChEMBL
element.label: Cm
element.author: Anna Gaulton, Louisa J. Bellis, A. Patricia Bento, Jon Chambers, Mark Davies, Anne Hersey, Yvonne Light, Shaun McGlinchey, David Michalovich, Bissan Al-Lazikani and John P. Overington
element.about: ChEMBL is a database of bioactive drug-like small molecules, it contains 2-D structures, calculated properties (e.g. logP, Molecular Weight, Lipinski Parameters, etc.) and abstracted bioactivities (e.g. binding constants, pharmacology and ADMET data).

element.name: ChEBI
element.label: Cb
element.author: Hastings, J., de Matos, P., Dekker, A., Ennis, M., Harsha, B., Kale, N., Muthukrishnan, V., Owen, G., Turner, S., Williams, M., and Steinbeck, C.
element.about: Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI) is a freely available dictionary of molecular entities focused on ‘small’ chemical compounds. The term ‘molecular entity’ refers to any constitutionally or isotopically distinct atom, molecule, ion, ion pair, radical, radical ion, complex, conformer, etc., identifiable as a separately distinguishable entity. The molecular entities in question are either products of nature or synthetic products used to intervene in the processes of living organisms.

element.label: Bl
element.name: BLAT
element.about: BLAT is a bioinformatics software a tool which performs rapid mRNA/DNA and cross-species protein alignments. BLAT is more accurate and 500 times faster than popular existing tools for mRNA/DNA alignments and 50 times faster for protein alignments at sensitivity settings typically used when comparing vertebrate sequences.
element.author: Jim Kent

element.label: Vm
element.name: VMATCH
element.author: Stefan Kurtz
element.about: Vmatch, a versatile software tool for efficiently solving large scale sequence matching tasks.

element.name: Rnnotator
element.label: Rt
element.author: Martin J, Bruno VM, Fang Z, Meng X, Blow M, Zhang T, Sherlock G, Snyder M, Wang Z
element.about: Comprehensive annotation and quantification of transcriptomes are outstanding problems in functional genomics. Rnnotator is an automated software pipeline that generates transcript models by de novo assembly of RNA-Seq data without the need for a reference genome. The contigs produced by Rnnotator are highly accurate and reconstruct fulllength genes when transcripts are sequenced sufficiently deep, roughly 30X for a given transcript. Rnnotator was designed to assemble Illumina single or paired-end reads. Rnnotator is also able to incorporate strand-specific RNA-Seq reads into the assembly in order to further improve the assembly.

element.name: ANNOVAR
element.label: Av
element.author: Liu X, JIan X, Boerwinkle E
element.about: ANNOVAR is an efficient software tool to utilize update-to-date information to functionally annotate genetic variants detected from diverse genomes (including human genome hg18, hg19, as well as mouse, worm, fly, yeast and many others).

element.label: Fg
element.name: FGENESH
element.author: Asaf Salamov and Victor Solovyev
element.about: HMM-based gene structure prediction (multiple genes, both chains).In recent rice genome sequencing projects, it was cited 'the most successful' (gene finding) program (Yu et al. (2002) Science 296:79) and was used to produce 87% of all high-evidence predicted genes (Goff et al. (2002) Science 296:79).
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Gn
element.name: GENSCAN
element.author: Chris Burge
element.about: GENSCAN is an program to identify complete gene structures in genomic DNA.

element.label: Bh
element.author: Peter D Karp, Thomas J Lee, Yannick Pouliot, Valerie Wagner, Tomer Altman, Nan Guo and David Dunkely.
element.about: BioWarehouse is an open-source software environment for integrating a set of biological databases into a single physical database management system for data management, mining, and exploration.
element.name: BioWarehouse

element.label: Ga
element.name: GATK
element.author: Aaron McKenna, Matthew Hanna, Eric Banks, Andrey Sivachenko, Kristian Cibulskis, Andrew Kernytsky, Kiran Garimella, David Altshuler, Stacey Gabriel, Mark Daly and Mark DePristo
element.about: Say you have ten exomes and you want to identify the rare mutations they all have in common – the GATK can do that. Or you need to know which mutations are specific to a group of patients, as opposed to a healthy cohort – the GATK can do that too. In fact, the GATK is the industry standard for such analyses.
element.licence: BSD style licence: For non-commercial use only. GATK-lite can used for commercial operations

element.label: Pm
element.author: Ziheng Yang
element.about: PAML is a package of programs for phylogenetic analyses of DNA or protein sequences using maximum likelihood.
element.name: PAML
element.os: UNIX, Linux, Mac OSX and Windows

element.label: Ro
element.name: ROSETTA
element.about: ROSETTA is a software suite for predicting and designing protein structures, protein folding mechanisms, and protein-protein interactions.
element.author: David Baker, et al

element.label: Cr
element.name: Chimera
element.about: UCSF Chimera is a highly extensible program for interactive visualization and analysis of molecular structures and related data, including density maps, supramolecular assemblies, sequence alignments, docking results, trajectories, and conformational ensembles. High-quality images and animations can be generated. Chimera includes complete documentation and several tutorials, and can be downloaded free of charge for academic, government, non-profit, and personal use.
element.author: Pettersen, Goddard, Huang, Couch, Greenblatt, Meng, and Ferrin

element.label: Dl
element.name: Dali
element.about: This server computes optimal and suboptimal structural alignments between two protein structures using the DaliLite -pairwise option (version 3.1). It will compare all chains in the first structure against all chains in the second (unless chain IDs are given). The resulting superimposed coordinate files can be downloaded or viewed interactively in Jmol (requires Java).
element.author: Hasegawa, Holm
element.licence: Custom licence, commercial users must pay

element.label: Pc
element.name: PCAP
element.author: Xiaoqui Huang
element.about: Parallel contig assembly program (PCAP) for assembling tens of millions of reads into long sequences.

element.label: Cm
element.author: Phil Green
element.about: Cross_match is a program for rapid protein and nucleic acid sequence comparison and database search, based on an efficient implementation of the Smith-Waterman-Gotoh algorithm (Smith & Waterman 1981, Gotoh 1982). By revising the recursion relations slightly and making efficient use of word-packing, we have been able to significantly reduce the number of machine instructions executed per Smith-Waterman matrix cell, resulting in a speed enhancement of 2-3 fold over the previous best implementation (Pearson and Miller, 1992).
element.name: CROSSMATCH

element.label: Sh
element.name: SSAHA2
element.about: SSAHA2 (Sequence Search and Alignment by Hashing Algorithm) is a pairwise sequence alignment program designed for the efficient mapping of sequencing reads onto genomic reference sequences. SSAHA2 reads of most sequencing platforms (ABI-Sanger, Roche 454, Illumina-Solexa) and a range of output formats (SAM, CIGAR, PSL etc.) are supported. A pile-up pipeline for analysis and genotype calling is available as a separate package.
element.author: Adam Spargo, Zemin Ning, James Mullikin, Tony Cox and Nikolai Ivanov.

element.name: MaskerAid
element.label: Md
element.author: Bedell JA, Korf I, Gish W.
element.about: Identifying and masking repetitive elements is usually the first step when analyzing vertebrate genomic sequence. Current repeat identification software is sensitive but slow, creating a costly bottleneck in large-scale analyses. We have developed MaskerAid, a software enhancement to RepeatMasker that increased the speed of masking more than 30-fold at the most sensitive setting.

element.label: Ab
element.name: ABYSS
element.author: Shuan Jackman, Tony Raymond and Jared Simpson
element.about: ABySS(Assembly By Short Sequencing) is a de novo, parallel, paired-end sequence assembler that is designed for short reads.

element.label: Mk
element.name: MAKER
element.author: Moj Eram and Mark Yandell
element.about: MAKER is a portable and easily configurable genome annotation pipeline. It's purpose is to allow smaller eukaryotic and prokaryotic genome projects to independently annotate their genomes and to create genome databases.

element.label: Mr
element.name: MiRDeep
element.author: Marc Friedlander and Nikolaus Rajewsky
element.about: The miRDeep package was developed to discover active known or novel miRNAs from deep sequencing data (Solexa/Illumina, 454). The package consists of everything you need to analyze your own deep sequencing data after removal of ligation adapters: a number of scripts to preprocess the mapped data, and the core miRDeep algorithm that will analyze and score these data.

element.label: Uc
element.name: UCSC
element.author: Meyer LR, Zweig AS, Hinrichs AS, Karolchik D, Kuhn RM, Wong M, Sloan CA, Rosenbloom KR, Roe G, Rhead B, Raney BJ, Pohl A, Malladi VS, Li CH, Lee BT, Learned K, Kirkup V, Hsu F, Heitner S, Harte RA, Haeussler M, Guruvadoo L, Goldman M, Giardine BM, Fujita PA, Dreszer TR, Diekhans M, Cline MS, Clawson H, Barber GP, Haussler D, and Kent WJ.
element.about: The UCSC Genome Browser and associated tools provide access to the sequences of human and other vertebrate genomes, as well as selected invertebrate model organisms. The Browser shows annotations of many types mapped to the coordinates of the reference assembly for each organism. Annotations include the locations of RNAs from the organism and from other organisms, DNA modifications (ENCODE project on human and mouse), SNPs, repeats and structural variations. The BLAT alignment tool allows alignment of sequences to the reference assemblies. The Table Browser offers an interface for access to the large underlying database.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Pt
element.author: Peter D. Karp
element.about: Pathway Tools is a comprehensive software environment that supports construction of organism-specific databases called Pathway/Genome Databases (PGDBs).
element.name: Pathway Tools

element.label: Sw
element.author: Dr. Matthew Stocks, Dr Daniel Mapleson, Dr. Hugh Woolfenden, Mr. Leighton Folkes and Irina-Ioana Mohorianu.
element.about: The UEA sRNA workbench is a new simple to use, downloadable sRNA software package based on algorithms developed for the original UEA sRNA Toolkit that will perform a complete analysis of single or multiple-sample sRNA datasets from both plants and animals to identify interesting landmarks (such as detection of novel micro RNA sequences) or other tasks such as profiling small RNA expression patterns in genetic data.
element.name: sRNA workbench UEA
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Mo
element.name: Modeller
element.about: MODELLER is used for homology or comparative modeling of protein three-dimensional structures (1,2). The user provides an alignment of a sequence to be modeled with known related structures and MODELLER automatically calculates a model containing all non-hydrogen atoms. MODELLER implements comparative protein structure modeling by satisfaction of spatial restraints (3,4), and can perform many additional tasks, including de novo modeling of loops in protein structures, optimization of various models of protein structure with respect to a flexibly defined objective function, multiple alignment of protein sequences and/or structures, clustering, searching of sequence databases, comparison of protein structures, etc.
element.author: Ben Webb, et al

element.label: Pm
element.name: PyMOL
element.about: PyMOL is a user-sponsored molecular visualization system on an open-source foundation. Please support development of this open, effective, and affordable software by purchasing an incentive copy, which is pre-built and comes with maintenance and support.
element.author: Warren Lyford DeLano
element.licence: Custom, older versions free for educational use

element.label: No
element.name: NOVOALIGN
element.about: Novoalign is a short-read mapper designed to be fast and sensitive on small to large genome databases. It's primary design is based on the use of read quality information and the need to assemble genomes from resequencing experiments. Novoalign supports fragment, paired-end and mate-pair reads from major sequencing platforms such as Illumina, SOLiD and Roche 454. NovoalignCS is the version of Novoalign developed for SOLiD colourspace reads.
element.author: Colin Hercus

element.label: Zm
element.name: ZOOM
element.author: Lin H., Zhang Z., Zhang MQ., Ma B., Li M.
element.about: Next generation sequencing researchers require accurate results, fast. ZOOM exceeds these needs. Using ZOOM, zillions of short reads are mapped back to reference genomes, including post-analysis at unparalleled in speed, at full sensitivity. Throughout the next few pages, ZOOM's features, capabilities, even benchmarking will be presented, to provide researchers with as much information about the software as possible. For unconvinced until truly relevant results are presented, ZOOM offers a free 30-day licenses to process private and public data from Illumina/SOLiD instruments.

element.label: Ca
element.author: Illumina
element.about: Illumina's Consensus Assessment of Sequence and Variation (CASAVA) software captures summary information for resequencing and counting studies and places the data in a compact structure for visualization within GenomeStudio Software or publicly available analysis tools. CASAVA can create genomic builds, call SNPs, detects indels, and count reads from data generated from one or more runs of the Genome Analyzer across a broad range of sequencing applications.
element.name: Casava

element.label: Oz
element.author: Victor Solovyev, Igor Seledtsov, Peter Kosarev, Vladimir Molodstov
element.about: OligoZip tool for processing short reads generated by Illumina-Solexa or similar sequencing machines. The tool does de novo reconstruction of genomc sequence, reconstruction of genomic sequences based on a reference genome for same or close species, mutation profiling and SNP discovery in a given set of genes.
element.name: OLIGOZIP

element.label: Ne
element.name: NEWBLER
element.author: Florent E Angly 'Roche'
element.about: The 454 Newbler Assembly is a de novo assembler that allows you to assemble your raw reads. Newbler was designed with the intent to be used with 454 data.

element.name: Genedata
element.label: Gd
element.about: The Genedata portfolio of advanced software solutions is built on an open, enterprise-level client-server architecture, which supports large-scale experimental research processes. Genedata solutions deliver a high degree of built-in-business logic, integration, performance, and scalability to researchers, scientists, and managers.

element.name: Integromics
element.label: It
element.about: Integromics S.L. provides state-of-the-art bioinformatics software solutions for data management and data analysis in genomics and proteomics. Our advanced software technology, supported by an experienced and knowledgeable team of life science professionals, enhances your ability to effectively organize your data, perform validated analyses, discover new biomedical knowledge and gain well-founded insights into various areas of research.

element.name: SRS
element.label: Sr
element.about: SRS is a proven and scalable data integration platform that is used at over 300 commercial and academic sites delivering genomic data to thousands of users. SRS facilitates the rapid development of applications and algorithms, as well as bioinformatics portals for the Internet or Intranet, making the data efficiently available to entire organizations.

element.name: GenePool
element.label: Gp
element.about: GenePool is a software system for analyzing and visualizing large-scale genomic data for biomarker discovery in clinical research and development.

element.name: Match
element.label: Mh
element.licence: Basic version free, Updated data commercial
element.author: Kel, A. E.; Goessling, E.; Reuter, I.; Cheremushkin, E.; Kel-Margoulis, O. V.; Wingender, E.
element.about: Match is a weight matrix-based program for predicting transcription factor binding sites (TFBS) in DNA sequences. It uses a library of positional weight matrices from TRANSFAC® Public 6.0.

element.name: geneXplain
element.label: Gp
element.about: The geneXplain platform is an online toolbox and workflow management system for a broad range of bioinformatic and systems biology applications. The individual modules, or Bricks, are unified under a standardized interface, with a consistent look-and-feel and can flexibly be put together to comprehensive workflows. The workflow management is intuitively handled through a simple drag-and-drop system. With this system, you can edit the predefined workflows or compose your own workflows from scratch. Own Bricks can easily be added as scripts or plug-ins and can be used in combination with pre-existing analyses.

element.label: Pp
element.name: PIPELINE PILOT
element.author: SciTegic
element.about: Pipeline Pilot is Accelrys’ graphical scientific workflow authoring application. Built on the scientifically aware Accelrys Enterprise Platform, Pipeline Pilot enables scientists to rapidly create, test and publish scientific services that automate the process of accessing, analyzing and reporting scientific data, either for the scientist’s personal use or for sharing across the scientific community.

element.label: Gs
element.name: GENESPRING
element.author: Agilent Technologies
element.about: GeneSpring provides powerful, accessible statistical tools for fast visualization and analysis of microarray data. Designed specifically for the needs of biologists, GeneSpring offers an interactive computing environment that promotes investigation and enables understanding of microarray data within a biological context.
element.os: Linux, Mac OS X and Windows

element.label: Gu
element.author: Drummond AJ, Ashton B, Buxton S, Cheung M, Cooper A, Duran C, Field M, Heled J, Kearse M, Markowitz S, Moir R, Stones-Havas S, Sturrock S, Thierer T, Wilson A (2011)
element.about: Geneious Pro is an integrated, cross-platform bioinformatics software suite for manipulating, finding, sharing, and exploring biological data such as DNA sequences or proteins, phylogenies, 3D structure information, publications, etc. It features sequence alignment and phylogenetic analysis, contig assembly, primer design and cloning, access to NCBI and UniProt, BLAST, protein structure viewing, automated PubMed searching, and more. It even includes an API for creating your own plugins.
element.name: Geneious Pro

element.label: Cb
element.author: CLC Bio
element.about: CLC bio is the world's leading bioinformatics solution provider and the only one that provides both desktop and server software seamlessly integrated and optimized for best performance. By developing their own proprietary algorithms, the scientists at CLC bio have successfully parallelized the data calculations to achieve remarkable improvements in speed over comparable solutions.
element.name: CLC BIO

element.label: An
element.author: Strand Scientific Intelligence
element.about: Avadis NGS is an integrated platform that provides analysis, management and visualization tools for next-generation sequencing data. It supports extensive workflows for alignment, RNA-Seq, small RNA-Seq, DNA-Seq, and ChIP-Seq experiments.
element.name: Avadis NGS

element.label: Pk
element.author: Partek
element.about: Partek's statistical analysis and data mining tools are based on proven methods that undergo rigorous testing to verify mathematical correctness, and our interactive 2-D and 3-D visualizations are linked together to facilitate powerful and intuitive exploratory data analysis.
element.name: Partek
